title: 105_hr1856
content: The Act is titled the "National Wildlife Refuge System Volunteer and Community Partnership Enhancement Act of 1998" and its purpose is outlined in the findings and purposes section. Congress finds that the National Wildlife Refuge System, with over 500 refuges and 93,000,000 acres, is crucial for protecting US natural resources. The National Wildlife Refuge System Improvement Act of 1997 enhanced refuge laws, but limited financial resources hinder implementation. Encouraging volunteer programs, donations, and non-Federal partnerships can supplement funding and maximize the benefits of the 1997 Act amendments. Additionally, promoting refuge educational programs is essential for public engagement. The National Wildlife Refuge System Improvement Act of 1997 aims to promote public awareness and participation in conservation efforts through volunteer programs, partnerships with non-Federal entities, and donations to the System. SEC. 3. GIFTS TO PARTICULAR NATIONAL WILDLIFE REFUGES. Section 7(b)(2) of the Fish and Wildlife Act of 1956 is amended to specify the use of gifts, devises, and bequests for the benefit of particular national wildlife refuges, ensuring that funds are disbursed only for the designated refuge without further appropriations. Matching funds may be provided by the Secretary subject to availability and relevant laws. The Secretary may provide funds to match gifts, devises, and bequests for the benefit of specific national wildlife refuges or related complexes, with the Federal funds not exceeding the value of the gift. SEC. 4. VOLUNTEER ENHANCEMENT. The Secretary of the Interior will conduct pilot projects at national wildlife refuges to employ volunteer coordinators responsible for recruiting, training, and supervising volunteers. These projects aim to enhance volunteer involvement and coordination with partner organizations. The Secretary of the Interior will conduct pilot projects at national wildlife refuges to employ volunteer coordinators responsible for recruiting, training, and supervising volunteers. A report evaluating the projects will be submitted to the House of Representatives and the Senate after 3 years. $2,000,000 is authorized for fiscal years 1999 through 2002. Amendments to the Fish and Wildlife Act of 1956 include providing awards and recognition for volunteers without regard to their places of residence. The Secretary of the Interior may establish a Senior Volunteer Corps for volunteers over the age of 50, with additional expenses provided to assist in recruitment and retention. SEC. 5. COMMUNITY PARTNERSHIP ENHANCEMENT. Section 7 of the Fish and Wildlife Act of 1956 is amended to include a definition of a partner organization and guidelines for cooperative agreements to enhance community partnerships in promoting conservation efforts for wildlife and historical resources. The Secretary of the Interior may enter into cooperative agreements with partner organizations, academic institutions, or State/local government agencies to carry out projects for wildlife refuges in accordance with the National Wildlife Refuge System Administration Act of 1966. The Secretary of the Interior can form partnerships with organizations, academic institutions, or government agencies to support wildlife refuges by promoting stewardship, maintaining habitats, improving facilities, increasing awareness, and advancing education. The Secretary of the Interior can partner with organizations, academic institutions, or government agencies to support wildlife refuges through educational programs, financial contributions, and federal funding matching non-Federal funds donated under cooperative agreements. The Secretary of the Interior can provide funds for projects or programs, but the amount cannot exceed the non-Federal funds donated. Federal funds can only be used for project expenses and not for non-Federal entity operations. Any new facilities or improvements constructed under this subsection belong to the United States Government. Amounts received from projects go to a Treasury account. Amounts received from projects and programs under subparagraph (B) will be deposited in a separate Treasury account. These funds can be used by the Secretary of the Interior for volunteer activities, incidental expenses, and cooperative agreements at specific refuges or groups of related refuges. SEC. 6. REFUGE EDUCATION PROGRAM DEVELOPMENT. The Fish and Wildlife Act of 1956 is amended to enhance the Refuge Education Program by providing outdoor classroom opportunities for students on national wildlife refuges and promoting understanding and conservation of fish, wildlife, plants, and cultural resources. The Fish and Wildlife Act of 1956 is amended to enhance the Refuge Education Program by providing outdoor classroom opportunities for students on national wildlife refuges. This includes promoting understanding and conservation of fish, wildlife, plants, cultural, and historical resources through education programs. The Secretary of the Interior may develop or enhance refuge education programs in cooperation with State and local education authorities and partner organizations. SEC. 7 of the Fish and Wildlife Act of 1956 authorizes $2,000,000 to the Secretary of the Interior for fiscal years 1999 through 2004 to carry out specific subsections.
